play.title: The First Part of Henry the Sixth

persona.persname: General of the French Force at Bordeaux
Ambassador from the Earl of Armagnac

stagedir.dir: Dead march. Enter the Funeral of King Henry the Fifth, attended on by the Duke of Bedford, the Duke of Gloucester, the Duke of Exeter, the Earl of Warwick, the Bishop of Winchester, and the Duke of Somerset; Heralds, etc.

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: My honorable lords, health to you all!
Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,
Of loss, of slaughter, and discomfiture:
Guienne, Champaigne, Rheims, Orleance,
Paris, Guysors, Poictiers, are all quite lost.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: What say’st thou, man, before dead Henry’s corse?
Speak softly, or the loss of those great towns
Will make him burst his lead and rise from death.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Is Paris lost? Is Roan yielded up?
If Henry were recall’d to life again,
These news would cause him once more yield the ghost.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: How were they lost? What treachery was us’d?

speech.speaker: 1. MESS.
speech.line: No treachery, but want of men and money.
Amongst the soldiers this is muttered,
That here you maintain several factions;
And whilst a field should be dispatch’d and fought,
You are disputing of your generals.
One would have ling’ring wars with little cost;
Another would fly swift, but wanteth wings;
A third thinks, without expense at all,
By guileful fair words peace may be obtain’d.
Awake, awake, English nobility!
Let not sloth dim your honors new begot.
Cropp’d are the flower-de-luces in your arms,
Of England’s coat one half is cut away.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: Were our tears wanting to this funeral,
These tidings would call forth her flowing tides.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: Me they concern, Regent I am of France.
Give me my steeled coat, I’ll fight for France.
Away with these disgraceful wailing robes!
Wounds will I lend the French in stead of eyes,
To weep their intermissive miseries.

speech.speaker: 2. MESS.
speech.line: Lords, view these letters full of bad mischance.
France is revolted from the English quite,
Except some petty towns of no import.
The Dauphin Charles is crowned king in Rheims;
The Bastard of Orleance with him is join’d;
Reignier, Duke of Anjou, doth take his part;
The Duke of Alanson flieth to his side.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: The Dauphin crowned king? All fly to him?
O, whither shall we fly from this reproach?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: We will not fly but to our enemies’ throats.
Bedford, if thou be slack, I’ll fight it out.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: Gloucester, why doubt’st thou of my forwardness?
An army have I muster’d in my thoughts,
Wherewith already France is overrun.

speech.speaker: 3. MESS.
speech.line: My gracious lords, to add to your laments,
Wherewith you now bedew King Henry’s hearse,
I must inform you of a dismal fight
Betwixt the stout Lord Talbot and the French.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: What? Wherein Talbot overcame, is’t so?

speech.speaker: 3. MESS.
speech.line: O no; wherein Lord Talbot was o’er-thrown.
The circumstance I’ll tell you more at large.
The tenth of August last this dreadful lord,
Retiring from the siege of Orleance,
Having full scarce six thousand in his troop,
By three and twenty thousand of the French
Was round encompassed, and set upon.
No leisure had he to enrank his men;
He wanted pikes to set before his archers;
In stead whereof sharp stakes pluck’d out of hedges
They pitched in the ground confusedly,
To keep the horsemen off from breaking in.
More than three hours the fight continued,
Where valiant Talbot above human thought
Enacted wonders with his sword and lance:
Hundreds he sent to hell, and none durst stand him;
Here, there, and every where, enrag’d he slew.
The French exclaim’d, the devil was in arms;
All the whole army stood agaz’d on him.
His soldiers, spying his undaunted spirit,
“A Talbot! A Talbot!” cried out amain,
And rush’d into the bowels of the battle.
Here had the conquest fully been seal’d up,
If Sir John Falstaff had not play’d the coward.
He, being in the vaward, plac’d behind
With purpose to relieve and follow them,
Cowardly fled, not having struck one stroke.
Hence grew the general wrack and massacre;
Enclosed were they with their enemies.
A base Wallon, to win the Dauphin’s grace,
Thrust Talbot with a spear into the back,
Whom all France with their chief assembled strength
Durst not presume to look once in the face.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: Is Talbot slain then? I will slay myself
For living idly here in pomp and ease,
Whilst such a worthy leader, wanting aid,
Unto his dastard foemen is betray’d.

speech.speaker: 3. MESS.
speech.line: O no, he lives, but is took prisoner,
And Lord Scales with him, and Lord Hungerford.
Most of the rest slaughter’d or took likewise.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: His ransom there is none but I shall pay:
I’ll hale the Dauphin headlong from his throne,
His crown shall be the ransom of my friend;
Four of their lords I’ll change for one of ours.
Farewell, my masters, to my task will I.
Bonfires in France forthwith I am to make,
To keep our great Saint George’s feast withal.
Ten thousand soldiers with me I will take,
Whose bloody deeds shall make all Europe quake.

speech.speaker: 3. MESS.
speech.line: So you had need, for Orleance is besieg’d;
The English army is grown weak and faint;
The Earl of Salisbury craveth supply,
And hardly keeps his men from mutiny,
Since they, so few, watch such a multitude.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: Remember, lords, your oaths to Henry sworn:
Either to quell the Dauphin utterly,
Or bring him in obedience to your yoke.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: I do remember it, and here take my leave,
To go about my preparation.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I’ll to the Tower with all the haste I can,
To view th’ artillery and munition,
And then I will proclaim young Henry king.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: To Eltam will I, where the young King is,
Being ordain’d his special governor,
And for his safety there I’ll best devise.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: Each hath his place and function to attend:
I am left out; for me nothing remains.
But long I will not be Jack out of office.
The King from Eltam I intend to send,
And sit at chiefest stern of public weal.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Mars his true moving, even as in the heavens,
So in the earth, to this day is not known.
Late did he shine upon the English side;
Now we are victors, upon us he smiles.
What towns of any moment but we have?
At pleasure here we lie near Orleance;
Otherwhiles the famish’d English, like pale ghosts,
Faintly besiege us one hour in a month.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: They want their porridge and their fat bull-beeves:
Either they must be dieted like mules
And have their provender tied to their mouths,
Or piteous they will look, like drowned mice.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: Let’s raise the siege; why live we idly here?
Talbot is taken, whom we wont to fear;
Remaineth none but mad-brain’d Salisbury,
And he may well in fretting spend his gall—
Nor men nor money hath he to make war.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Sound, sound alarum! We will rush on them.
Now for the honor of the forlorn French!
Him I forgive my death that killeth me,
When he sees me go back one foot or fly.

stagedir.dir: Here alarum; they are beaten back by the English with great loss.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Who ever saw the like? What men have I!
Dogs! Cowards! Dastards! I would ne’er have fled,
But that they left me midst my enemies.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: Salisbury is a desperate homicide,
He fighteth as one weary of his life.
The other lords, like lions wanting food,
Do rush upon us as their hungry prey.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Froissard, a countryman of ours, records
England all Olivers and Rolands bred
During the time Edward the Third did reign.
More truly now may this be verified,
For none but Samsons and Goliases
It sendeth forth to skirmish. One to ten!
Lean raw-bon’d rascals! Who would e’er suppose
They had such courage and audacity?

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Let’s leave this town, for they are hare-brain’d slaves,
And hunger will enforce them to be more eager.
Of old I know them; rather with their teeth
The walls they’ll tear down than forsake the siege.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: I think by some odd gimmors or device
Their arms are set, like clocks, still to strike on;
Else ne’er could they hold out so as they do.
By my consent, we’ll even let them alone.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Be it so.

scene.line: But first, to try her skill,
Reignier, stand thou as Dauphin in my place;
Question her proudly, let thy looks be stern.
By this means shall we sound what skill she hath.

stagedir.dir: Enter Joan de Pucelle and Bastard.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Stay, stay thy hands! Thou art an Amazon,
And fightest with the sword of Deborah.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Christ’s Mother helps me, else I were too weak.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Whoe’er helps thee, ’tis thou that must help me:
Impatiently I burn with thy desire;
My heart and hands thou hast at once subdu’d.
Excellent Pucelle, if thy name be so,
Let me thy servant and not sovereign be.
’Tis the French Dauphin sueth to thee thus.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: I must not yield to any rites of love,
For my profession’s sacred from above.
When I have chased all thy foes from hence,
Then will I think upon a recompense.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Mean time look gracious on thy prostrate thrall.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: My lord, methinks, is very long in talk.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Doubtless he shrives this woman to her smock,
Else ne’er could he so long protract his speech.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: Shall we disturb him, since he keeps no mean?

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: He may mean more than we poor men do know:
These women are shrewd tempters with their tongues.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: My lord, where are you? What devise you on?
Shall we give o’er Orleance, or no?

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Why, no, I say. Distrustful recreants,
Fight till the last gasp; I’ll be your guard.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: What she says I’ll confirm. We’ll fight it out.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Assign’d am I to be the English scourge.
This night the siege assuredly I’ll raise:
Expect Saint Martin’s summer, halcyons’ days,
Since I have entered into these wars.
Glory is like a circle in the water,
Which never ceaseth to enlarge itself,
Till by broad spreading it disperse to nought.
With Henry’s death the English circle ends,
Dispersed are the glories it included.
Now am I like that proud insulting ship
Which Caesar and his fortune bare at once.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Was Mahomet inspired with a dove?
Thou with an eagle art inspired then.
Helen, the mother of great Constantine,
Nor yet Saint Philip’s daughters, were like thee.
Bright star of Venus, fall’n down on the earth,
How may I reverently worship thee enough?

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Leave off delays, and let us raise the siege.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: Woman, do what thou canst to save our honors;
Drive them from Orleance and be immortaliz’d.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Presently we’ll try; come, let’s away about it.
No prophet will I trust, if she prove false.

stagedir.dir: Enter Gloucester with his Serving Attendants in blue coats.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: How now, ambitious Humphrey, what means this?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Peel’d priest, dost thou command me to be shut out?

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: I do, thou most usurping proditor,
And not Protector, of the King or realm.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Stand back, thou manifest conspirator,
Thou that contrivedst to murder our dead lord,
Thou that giv’st whores indulgences to sin.
I’ll canvass thee in thy broad cardinal’s hat,
If thou proceed in this thy insolence.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: Nay, stand thou back, I will not budge a foot:
This be Damascus, be thou cursed Cain,
To slay thy brother Abel, if thou wilt.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I will not slay thee, but I’ll drive thee back.
Thy scarlet robes as a child’s bearing-cloth
I’ll use to carry thee out of this place.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: Do what thou dar’st, I beard thee to thy face.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: What? Am I dar’d and bearded to my face?
Draw, men, for all this privileged place—
Blue coats to tawny coats! Priest, beware your beard,
I mean to tug it and to cuff you soundly.
Under my feet I stamp thy cardinal’s hat;
In spite of Pope or dignities of church,
Here by the cheeks I’ll drag thee up and down.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: Gloucester, thou wilt answer this before the Pope.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Winchester goose, I cry, “A rope! A rope!”
Now beat them hence, why do you let them stay?
Thee I’ll chase hence, thou wolf in sheep’s array.
Out, tawny-coats! Out, scarlet hypocrite!

stagedir.dir: Here Gloucester’s men beat out the Cardinal’s men, and enter in the hurly-burly the Mayor of London and his Officers.

speech.speaker: MAY.
speech.line: Fie, lords, that you, being supreme magistrates,
Thus contumeliously should break the peace!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Peace, Mayor, thou know’st little of my wrongs.
Here’s Beauford, that regards nor God nor king,
Hath here distrain’d the Tower to his use.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: Here’s Gloucester, a foe to citizens,
One that still motions war and never peace,
O’ercharging your free purses with large fines;
That seeks to overthrow religion
Because he is Protector of the realm,
And would have armor here out of the Tower,
To crown himself king and suppress the Prince.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: I will not answer thee with words, but blows.

speech.speaker: MAY.
speech.line: See the coast clear’d, and then we will depart.
Good God, these nobles should such stomachs bear!
I myself fight not once in forty year.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Master Gunner of Orléans and his Boy.

speech.speaker: M. GUN. BOY.
speech.line: Father, I warrant you, take you no care,
I’ll never trouble you, if I may spy them.

stagedir.dir: Enter Salisbury and Talbot, Sir William Glansdale, Sir Thomas Gargrave, on the turrets, with others.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: I grieve to hear what torments you endur’d,
But we will be reveng’d sufficiently.
Now it is supper-time in Orleance:
Here, through this grate, I count each one,
And view the Frenchmen how they fortify.
Let us look in, the sight will much delight thee.
Sir Thomas Gargrave, and Sir William Glansdale,
Let me have your express opinions,
Where is best place to make our batt’ry next?

speech.speaker: GAR.
speech.line: I think at the North Gate, for there stands lords.

speech.speaker: GLAN.
speech.line: And I here, at the bulwark of the bridge.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: For aught I see, this city must be famish’d,
Or with light skirmishes enfeebled.

stagedir.dir: Here they shoot, and Salisbury falls down together with Gargrave.

speech.speaker: 4. MESS.
speech.line: My lord, my lord, the French have gather’d head.
The Dauphin, with one Joan de Pucelle join’d,
A holy prophetess new risen up,
Is come with a great power to raise the siege.

stagedir.dir: Here Salisbury lifteth himself up and groans.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Hear, hear how dying Salisbury doth groan!
It irks his heart he cannot be reveng’d.
Frenchmen, I’ll be a Salisbury to you.
Pucelle or puzzel, Dauphin or dogfish,
Your hearts I’ll stamp out with my horse’s heels,
And make a quagmire of your mingled brains.
Convey me Salisbury into his tent,
And then we’ll try what these dastard Frenchmen dare.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Exeunt bearing out the bodies.
Here an alarum again, and Talbot pursueth the Dauphin, and driveth him.
Then enter Joan De Pucelle, driving Englishmen before her, and exit after them.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Where is my strength, my valor, and my force?
Our English troops retire, I cannot stay them;
A woman clad in armor chaseth them.
Here, here she comes. I’ll have a bout with thee;
Devil or devil’s dam, I’ll conjure thee.
Blood will I draw on thee—thou art a witch—
And straightway give thy soul to him thou serv’st.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Come, come, ’tis only I that must disgrace thee.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: My thoughts are whirled like a potter’s wheel,
I know not where I am, nor what I do.
A witch by fear, not force, like Hannibal,
Drives back our troops and conquers as she lists:
So bees with smoke and doves with noisome stench
Are from their hives and houses driven away.
They call’d us for our fierceness English dogs,
Now, like to whelps, we crying run away.
Hark, countrymen, either renew the fight,
Or tear the lions out of England’s coat;
Renounce your soil, give sheep in lions’ stead:
Sheep run not half so treacherous from the wolf,
Or horse or oxen from the leopard,
As you fly from your oft-subdued slaves.

stagedir.dir: Flourish. Enter on the walls Pucelle, Charles the Dauphin, Reignier, Alanson, and Soldiers.

speech.speaker: FR. SERG.
speech.line: Sirs, take your places and be vigilant.
If any noise or soldier you perceive
Near to the walls, by some apparent sign
Let us have knowledge at the court of guard.

speech.speaker: 1. SENT.
speech.line: Sergeant, you shall.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,
By whose approach the regions of Artois,
Wallon, and Picardy are friends to us,
This happy night the Frenchmen are secure,
Having all day carous’d and banqueted:
Embrace we then this opportunity
As fitting best to quittance their deceit
Contriv’d by art and baleful sorcery.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: Coward of France, how much he wrongs his fame,
Despairing of his own arm’s fortitude,
To join with witches and the help of hell!

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: Traitors have never other company.
But what’s that Pucelle whom they term so pure?

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: A maid, they say.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: A maid? And be so martial?

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: Pray God she prove not masculine ere long,
If underneath the standard of the French
She carry armor as she hath begun.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Well, let them practice and converse with spirits.
God is our fortress, in whose conquering name
Let us resolve to scale their flinty bulwarks.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: Ascend, brave Talbot, we will follow thee.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Not all together. Better far, I guess,
That we do make our entrance several ways;
That, if it chance the one of us do fail,
The other yet may rise against their force.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: Agreed. I’ll to yond corner.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: And I to this.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: And here will Talbot mount, or make his grave.
Now, Salisbury, for thee, and for the right
Of English Henry, shall this night appear
How much in duty I am bound to both.

speech.speaker: 1. SENT.
speech.line: Arm, arm! The enemy doth make assault!

stagedir.dir: The French leap o’er the walls in their shirts. Enter, several ways, Bastard, Alanson, Reignier, half ready and half unready.

speech.speaker: BAST.
speech.line: Tut, holy Joan was his defensive guard.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitful dame?
Didst thou at first, to flatter us withal,
Make us partakers of a little gain,
That now our loss might be ten times so much?

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend?
At all times will you have my power alike?
Sleeping or waking, must I still prevail,
Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?
Improvident soldiers, had your watch been good,
This sudden mischief never could have fall’n.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Duke of Alanson, this was your default,
That, being captain of the watch tonight,
Did look no better to that weighty charge.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Had all your quarters been as safely kept
As that whereof I had the government,
We had not been thus shamefully surpris’d.

speech.speaker: BAST.
speech.line: Mine was secure.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: And so was mine, my lord.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: And for myself, most part of all this night,
Within her quarter and mine own precinct
I was employ’d in passing to and fro,
About relieving of the sentinels.
Then how, or which way, should they first break in?

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Question, my lords, no further of the case,
How or which way. ’Tis sure they found some place
But weakly guarded, where the breach was made.
And now there rests no other shift but this,
To gather our soldiers, scatter’d and dispers’d,
And lay new platforms to endamage them.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Enter an English Soldier crying, “A Talbot! A Talbot!”

speech.speaker: ENG. SOLD.
speech.line: I’ll be so bold to take what they have left.
The cry of Talbot serves me for a sword,
For I have loaden me with many spoils,
Using no other weapon but his name.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: The day begins to break, and night is fled,
Whose pitchy mantle over-veil’d the earth.
Here sound retreat, and cease our hot pursuit.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Bring forth the body of old Salisbury,
And here advance it in the market-place,
The middle centure of this cursed town.
Now have I paid my vow unto his soul;
For every drop of blood was drawn from him
There hath at least five Frenchmen died tonight.
And that hereafter ages may behold
What ruin happened in revenge of him,
Within their chiefest temple I’ll erect
A tomb, wherein his corpse shall be interr’d;
Upon the which, that every one may read,
Shall be engrav’d the sack of Orleance,
The treacherous manner of his mournful death,
And what a terror he had been to France.
But, lords, in all our bloody massacre,
I muse we met not with the Dauphin’s grace,
His new-come champion, virtuous Joan of Aire,
Nor any of his false confederates.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: ’Tis thought, Lord Talbot, when the fight began,
Rous’d on the sudden from their drowsy beds,
They did amongst the troops of armed men
Leap o’er the walls for refuge in the field.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: Myself, as far as I could well discern
For smoke and dusky vapors of the night,
Am sure I scar’d the Dauphin and his trull,
When arm in arm they both came swiftly running,
Like to a pair of loving turtle-doves
That could not live asunder day or night.
After that things are set in order here,
We’ll follow them with all the power we have.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: Porter, remember what I gave in charge,
And when you have done so, bring the keys to me.

speech.speaker: PORT.
speech.line: Madam, I will.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: The plot is laid. If all things fall out right,
I shall as famous be by this exploit
As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus’ death.
Great is the rumor of this dreadful knight,
And his achievements of no less account;
Fain would mine eyes be witness with mine ears
To give their censure of these rare reports.

stagedir.dir: Enter Messenger of the Countess and Talbot.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: If thou be he, then art thou prisoner.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Prisoner? To whom?

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: To me, blood-thirsty lord;
And for that cause I train’d thee to my house.
Long time thy shadow hath been thrall to me,
For in my gallery thy picture hangs;
But now the substance shall endure the like,
And I will chain these legs and arms of thine,
That hast by tyranny these many years
Wasted our country, slain our citizens,
And sent our sons and husbands captivate.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha!

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: Laughest thou, wretch? Thy mirth shall turn to moan.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: I laugh to see your ladyship so fond
To think that you have aught but Talbot’s shadow
Whereon to practice your severity.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: Why? Art not thou the man?

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: I am indeed.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: Then have I substance too.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: No, no, I am but shadow of myself.
You are deceiv’d, my substance is not here;
For what you see is but the smallest part
And least proportion of humanity.
I tell you, madam, were the whole frame here,
It is of such a spacious lofty pitch,
Your roof were not sufficient to contain’t.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: This is a riddling merchant for the nonce:
He will be here, and yet he is not here.
How can these contrarieties agree?

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: That will I show you presently.

stagedir.dir: Winds his horn. Drums strike up; a peal of ordinance.

speech.line: How say you, madam? Are you now persuaded
That Talbot is but shadow of himself?
These are his substance, sinews, arms, and strength,
With which he yoketh your rebellious necks,
Razeth your cities, and subverts your towns,
And in a moment makes them desolate.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: Victorious Talbot, pardon my abuse.
I find thou art no less than fame hath bruited,
And more than may be gathered by thy shape.
Let my presumption not provoke thy wrath,
For I am sorry that with reverence
I did not entertain thee as thou art.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Be not dismay’d, fair lady, nor misconster
The mind of Talbot, as you did mistake
The outward composition of his body.
What you have done hath not offended me;
Nor other satisfaction do I crave,
But only, with your patience, that we may
Taste of your wine and see what cates you have,
For soldiers’ stomachs always serve them well.

speech.speaker: COUNT.
speech.line: With all my heart, and think me honored
To feast so great a warrior in my house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Richard Plantagenet, Warwick, Somerset, Pole the Earl of Suffolk, and others; Vernon and a Lawyer.

scene.line: In sign whereof I pluck a white rose too.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Now, Somerset, where is your argument?

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Here in my scabbard, meditating that
Shall dye your white rose in a bloody red.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Mean time your cheeks do counterfeit our roses;
For pale they look with fear, as witnessing
The truth on our side.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: No, Plantagenet;
’Tis not for fear, but anger, that thy cheeks
Blush for pure shame to counterfeit our roses,
And yet thy tongue will not confess thy error.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Hath not thy rose a canker, Somerset?

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Hath not thy rose a thorn, Plantagenet?

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Ay, sharp and piercing, to maintain his truth,
Whiles thy consuming canker eats his falsehood.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Well, I’ll find friends to wear my bleeding roses,
That shall maintain what I have said is true,
Where false Plantagenet dare not be seen.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Now, by this maiden blossom in my hand,
I scorn thee and thy fashion, peevish boy.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Turn not thy scorns this way, Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Proud Pole, I will, and scorn both him and thee.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: I’ll turn my part thereof into thy throat.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Away, away, good William de la Pole!
We grace the yeoman by conversing with him.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Now, by God’s will, thou wrong’st him, Somerset;
His grandfather was Lionel Duke of Clarence,
Third son to the third Edward, King of England.
Spring crestless yeomen from so deep a root?

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: He bears him on the place’s privilege,
Or durst not for his craven heart say thus.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: By Him that made me, I’ll maintain my words
On any plot of ground in Christendom.
Was not thy father, Richard Earl of Cambridge,
For treason executed in our late king’s days?
And by his treason, stand’st not thou attainted,
Corrupted, and exempt from ancient gentry?
His trespass yet lives guilty in thy blood,
And till thou be restor’d, thou art a yeoman.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: My father was attached, not attainted,
Condemn’d to die for treason, but no traitor;
And that I’ll prove on better men than Somerset,
Were growing time once ripened to my will.
For your partaker Pole, and you yourself,
I’ll note you in my book of memory,
To scourge you for this apprehension.
Look to it well, and say you are well warn’d.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Ah, thou shalt find us ready for thee still;
And know us by these colors for thy foes,
For these my friends in spite of thee shall wear.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: And, by my soul, this pale and angry rose,
As cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,
Will I forever and my faction wear,
Until it wither with me to my grave,
Or flourish to the height of my degree.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Go forward, and be chok’d with thy ambition!
And so farewell until I meet thee next.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: How I am brav’d, and must perforce endure it!

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: This blot that they object against your house
Shall be wip’d out in the next parliament,
Call’d for the truce of Winchester and Gloucester;
And if thou be not then created York,
I will not live to be accounted Warwick.
Mean time, in signal of my love to thee,
Against proud Somerset and William Pole,
Will I upon thy party wear this rose.
And here I prophesy: this brawl today,
Grown to this faction in the Temple Garden,
Shall send between the Red Rose and the White
A thousand souls to death and deadly night.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Good Master Vernon, I am bound to you
That you on my behalf would pluck a flower.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: In your behalf still will I wear the same.

speech.speaker: LAW.
speech.line: And so will I.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Thanks, gentlemen.
Come, let us four to dinner. I dare say
This quarrel will drink blood another day.

scene.scenelocation: London. A room in the Tower of London.

stagedir.dir: Enter Mortimer, brought in a chair, and Keepers.

speech.speaker: 1. KEEPER.
speech.line: My lord, your loving nephew now is come.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Ay, noble uncle, thus ignobly us’d,
Your nephew, late-despised Richard, comes.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: Direct mine arms I may embrace his neck,
And in his bosom spend my latter gasp.
O, tell me when my lips do touch his cheeks,
That I may kindly give one fainting kiss.
And now declare, sweet stem from York’s great stock,
Why didst thou say, of late thou wert despis’d?

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: First, lean thine aged back against mine arm,
And in that ease, I’ll tell thee my disease.
This day, in argument upon a case,
Some words there grew ’twixt Somerset and me;
Among which terms he us’d his lavish tongue
And did upbraid me with my father’s death;
Which obloquy set bars before my tongue,
Else with the like I had requited him.
Therefore, good uncle, for my father’s sake,
In honor of a true Plantagenet,
And for alliance sake, declare the cause
My father, Earl of Cambridge, lost his head.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: That cause, fair nephew, that imprison’d me
And hath detain’d me all my flow’ring youth
Within a loathsome dungeon, there to pine,
Was cursed instrument of his decease.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Discover more at large what cause that was,
For I am ignorant and cannot guess.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: I will, if that my fading breath permit
And death approach not ere my tale be done.
Henry the Fourth, grandfather to this king,
Depos’d his nephew Richard, Edward’s son,
The first begotten, and the lawful heir
Of Edward king, the third of that descent;
During whose reign the Percies of the north,
Finding his usurpation most unjust,
Endeavor’d my advancement to the throne.
The reason mov’d these warlike lords to this
Was, for that (young Richard thus remov’d,
Leaving no heir begotten of his body)
I was the next by birth and parentage;
For by my mother I derived am
From Lionel Duke of Clarence, third son
To King Edward the Third; whereas he
From John of Gaunt doth bring his pedigree,
Being but fourth of that heroic line.
But mark: as in this haughty great attempt
They labored to plant the rightful heir,
I lost my liberty, and they their lives.
Long after this, when Henry the Fifth
(Succeeding his father Bullingbrook) did reign,
Thy father, Earl of Cambridge then, deriv’d
From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of York,
Marrying my sister that thy mother was,
Again, in pity of my hard distress,
Levied an army, weening to redeem
And have install’d me in the diadem.
But as the rest, so fell that noble earl,
And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,
In whom the title rested, were suppress’d.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Of which, my lord, your honor is the last.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: True; and thou seest that I no issue have,
And that my fainting words do warrant death.
Thou art my heir; the rest I wish thee gather;
But yet be wary in thy studious care.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Thy grave admonishments prevail with me.
But yet methinks, my father’s execution
Was nothing less than bloody tyranny.

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: With silence, nephew, be thou politic.
Strong fixed is the house of Lancaster,
And like a mountain, not to be remov’d.
But now thy uncle is removing hence,
As princes do their courts, when they are cloy’d
With long continuance in a settled place.

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: O uncle, would some part of my young years
Might but redeem the passage of your age!

speech.speaker: MOR.
speech.line: Thou dost then wrong me, as that slaughterer doth
Which giveth many wounds when one will kill.
Mourn not, except thou sorrow for my good,
Only give order for my funeral.
And so farewell, and fair be all thy hopes,
And prosperous be thy life in peace and war!

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: And peace, no war, befall thy parting soul!
In prison hast thou spent a pilgrimage,
And like a hermit overpass’d thy days.
Well, I will lock his counsel in my breast,
And what I do imagine, let that rest.
Keepers, convey him hence, and I myself
Will see his burial better than his life.

stagedir.dir: Exeunt Keepers, bearing out the body of Mortimer.
Flourish. Enter King, Exeter, Gloucester, Winchester, Warwick, Somerset, Suffolk, Richard Plantagenet, and others.

scene.line: My lord, it were your duty to forbear.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Ay, so the Bishop be not overborne.
Methinks my lord should be religious,
And know the office that belongs to such.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Methinks his lordship should be humbler,
It fitteth not a prelate so to plead.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Yes, when his holy state is touch’d so near.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: State holy or unhallow’d, what of that?
Is not his Grace Protector to the King?

speech.speaker: PLAN.
speech.line: Plantagenet, I see, must hold his tongue,
Lest it be said, “Speak, sirrah, when you should;
Must your bold verdict enter talk with lords?”
Else would I have a fling at Winchester.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Uncles of Gloucester and of Winchester,
The special watchmen of our English weal,
I would prevail, if prayers might prevail,
To join your hearts in love and amity.
O, what a scandal is it to our crown
That two such noble peers as ye should jar!
Believe me, lords, my tender years can tell,
Civil dissension is a viperous worm
That gnaws the bowels of the commonwealth.
“Down with the tawny-coats!”
What tumult’s this?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: An uproar, I dare warrant,
Begun through malice of the Bishop’s men.
“Stones! Stones!”

speech.speaker: MAY.
speech.line: O my good lords, and virtuous Henry,
Pity the city of London, pity us!
The Bishop and the Duke of Gloucester’s men,
Forbidden late to carry any weapon,
Have fill’d their pockets full of pebble stones;
And, banding themselves in contrary parts,
Do pelt so fast at one another’s pate
That many have their giddy brains knock’d out;
Our windows are broke down in every street,
And we, for fear, compell’d to shut our shops.

stagedir.dir: Enter Servingmen of both parties, in skirmish, with bloody pates.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: You of my household, leave this peevish broil,
And set this unaccustom’d fight aside.

speech.speaker: 2. GLOU. SERV. ATT.
speech.line: My lord, we know your Grace to be a man
Just and upright; and, for your royal birth,
Inferior to none but to his Majesty;
And ere that we will suffer such a prince,
So kind a father of the commonweal,
To be disgraced by an inkhorn mate,
We and our wives and children all will fight,
And have our bodies slaught’red by thy foes.

speech.speaker: WIN. SERV. ATT.
speech.line: Ay, and the very parings of our nails
Shall pitch a field when we are dead.

scene.line: Ay, but, I fear me, with a hollow heart.—
See here, my friends and loving countrymen,
This token serveth for a flag of truce
Betwixt ourselves and all our followers.
So help me God, as I dissemble not!

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: So help me God, as I intend it not!

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: O loving uncle, kind Duke of Gloucester,
How joyful am I made by this contract!
Away, my masters, trouble us no more,
But join in friendship, as your lords have done.

speech.speaker: WIN. SERV. ATT.
speech.line: Content, I’ll to the surgeon’s.

speech.speaker: 1. GLOU. SERV. ATT.
speech.line: And so will I.

speech.speaker: 2. GLOU. SERV. ATT.
speech.line: And I will see what physic the tavern affords.

scene.line: Perish, base prince, ignoble Duke of York!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Now will it best avail your Majesty
To cross the seas and to be crown’d in France.
The presence of a king engenders love
Amongst his subjects and his loyal friends,
As it disanimates his enemies.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: When Gloucester says the word, King Henry goes,
For friendly counsel cuts off many foes.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Your ships already are in readiness.

stagedir.dir: Enter Pucelle, disguis’d, with four Soldiers with sacks upon their backs.
Enter Charles, Bastard, Alanson, Reignier, and forces.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Behold, this is the happy wedding torch
That joineth Roan unto her countrymen,
But burning fatal to the Talbonites!

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: France, thou shalt rue this treason with thy tears,
If Talbot but survive thy treachery.
Pucelle, that witch, that damned sorceress,
Hath wrought this hellish mischief unawares,
That hardly we escap’d the pride of France.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Good morrow, gallants, want ye corn for bread?
I think the Duke of Burgundy will fast
Before he’ll buy again at such a rate.
’Twas full of darnel; do you like the taste?

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: Scoff on, vile fiend and shameless courtezan!
I trust ere long to choke thee with thine own,
And make thee curse the harvest of that corn.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Your Grace may starve, perhaps, before that time.

speech.speaker: BED.
speech.line: O, let no words, but deeds, revenge this treason!

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: What will you do, good greybeard? Break a lance,
And run a-tilt at Death within a chair?

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Foul fiend of France, and hag of all despite,
Encompass’d with thy lustful paramours!
Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant age,
And twit with cowardice a man half dead?
Damsel, I’ll have a bout with you again,
Or else let Talbot perish with this shame.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Are ye so hot, sir? Yet, Pucelle, hold thy peace,
If Talbot do but thunder, rain will follow.

stagedir.dir: They, the English, whisper together in council.

speech.line: God speed the parliament! Who shall be the speaker?

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Dare ye come forth and meet us in the field?

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Belike your lordship takes us then for fools,
To try if that our own be ours or no.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: I speak not to that railing Hecate,
But unto thee, Alanson, and the rest.
Will ye, like soldiers, come and fight it out?

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Signior, no.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Signior, hang! Base muleters of France!
Like peasant footboys do they keep the walls,
And dare not take up arms like gentlemen.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Away, captains, let’s get us from the walls,
For Talbot means no goodness by his looks.
God buy, my lord, we came but to tell you
That we are here.

stagedir.dir: An alarum. Excursions. Enter Sir John Falstaff and a Captain.

speech.speaker: CAPT.
speech.line: Cowardly knight, ill fortune follow thee!

stagedir.dir: An alarum. Enter Talbot, Burgundy, and the rest.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Dismay not, princes, at this accident,
Nor grieve that Roan is so recovered:
Care is no cure, but rather corrosive,
For things that are not to be remedied.
Let frantic Talbot triumph for a while,
And like a peacock sweep along his tail;
We’ll pull his plumes and take away his train,
If Dauphin and the rest will be but rul’d.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: We have been guided by thee hitherto,
And of thy cunning had no diffidence;
One sudden foil shall never breed distrust.

speech.speaker: BAST.
speech.line: Search out thy wit for secret policies,
And we will make thee famous through the world.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: We’ll set thy statue in some holy place,
And have thee reverenc’d like a blessed saint.
Employ thee then, sweet virgin, for our good.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Then thus it must be, this doth Joan devise:
By fair persuasions, mix’d with sug’red words,
We will entice the Duke of Burgundy
To leave the Talbot and to follow us.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Ay, marry, sweeting, if we could do that,
France were no place for Henry’s warriors,
Nor should that nation boast it so with us,
But be extirped from our provinces.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Forever should they be expuls’d from France,
And not have title of an earldom here.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Your honors shall perceive how I will work
To bring this matter to the wished end.

stagedir.dir: Enter the Duke of Burgundy and forces.

speech.line: I am vanquished. These haughty words of hers
Have batt’red me like roaring cannon-shot,
And made me almost yield upon my knees.—
Forgive me, country, and sweet countrymen,
And, lords, accept this hearty kind embrace.
My forces and my power of men are yours.
So farewell, Talbot, I’ll no longer trust thee.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Done like a Frenchman—turn and turn again!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Welcome, brave Duke, thy friendship makes us fresh.

speech.speaker: BAST.
speech.line: And doth beget new courage in our breasts.

speech.speaker: ALAN.
speech.line: Pucelle hath bravely play’d her part in this,
And doth deserve a coronet of gold.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Now let us on, my lords, and join our powers,
And seek how we may prejudice the foe.

scene.scenelocation: Paris. A room in the palace.

stagedir.dir: Enter the King, Gloucester, Winchester, Richard Plantagenet, now Duke of York, Suffolk, Somerset, Warwick, Exeter, Vernon, Basset, and others. To them, with his Soldiers, Talbot.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Now, sir, to you, that were so hot at sea,
Disgracing of these colors that I wear
In honor of my noble Lord of York,
Dar’st thou maintain the former words thou spak’st?

speech.speaker: BAS.
speech.line: Yes, sir, as well as you dare patronage
The envious barking of your saucy tongue
Against my lord the Duke of Somerset.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Sirrah, thy lord I honor as he is.

speech.speaker: BAS.
speech.line: Why, what is he? As good a man as York.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Hark ye; not so; in witness, take ye that.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Lord Bishop, set the crown upon his head.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: God save King Henry, of that name the sixt!

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Now, Governor of Paris, take your oath:
That you elect no other king but him;
Esteem none friends but such as are his friends,
And none your foes but such as shall pretend
Malicious practices against his state.
This shall ye do, so help you righteous God!

speech.speaker: FAL.
speech.line: My gracious sovereign, as I rode from Callice,
To haste unto your coronation,
A letter was deliver’d to my hands,
Writ to your Grace from th’ Duke of Burgundy.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Shame to the Duke of Burgundy and thee!
I vow’d, base knight, when I did meet thee next,
To tear the Garter from thy craven’s leg,
Which I have done, because (unworthily)
Thou wast installed in that high degree.
Pardon me, princely Henry, and the rest.
This dastard, at the battle of Poictiers,
When (but in all) I was six thousand strong
And that the French were almost ten to one,
Before we met, or that a stroke was given,
Like to a trusty squire did run away;
In which assault we lost twelve hundred men;
Myself and divers gentlemen beside
Were there surpris’d and taken prisoners.
Then judge, great lords, if I have done amiss;
Or whether that such cowards ought to wear
This ornament of knighthood, yea or no?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: To say the truth, this fact was infamous
And ill beseeming any common man,
Much more a knight, a captain, and a leader.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: When first this order was ordain’d, my lords,
Knights of the Garter were of noble birth,
Valiant and virtuous, full of haughty courage,
Such as were grown to credit by the wars;
Not fearing death, nor shrinking for distress,
But always resolute in most extremes.
He then, that is not furnish’d in this sort,
Doth but usurp the sacred name of knight,
Profaning this most honorable order,
And should (if I were worthy to be judge)
Be quite degraded, like a hedge-born swain
That doth presume to boast of gentle blood.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Stain to thy countrymen, thou hear’st thy doom!
Be packing therefore, thou that wast a knight;
Henceforth we banish thee, on pain of death.

line.recite: Mov’d with compassion of my country’s wrack,
Of such as your oppression feeds upon,
And join’d with Charles, the rightful King of France.”

speech.line: O monstrous treachery! Can this be so?
That in alliance, amity, and oaths,
There should be found such false dissembling guile?

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What? Doth my uncle Burgundy revolt?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: He doth, my lord, and is become your foe.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Is that the worst this letter doth contain?

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: It is the worst, and all, my lord, he writes.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Why then Lord Talbot there shall talk with him,
And give him chastisement for this abuse.
How say you, my lord? Are you not content?

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Content, my liege? Yes. But that I am prevented,
I should have begg’d I might have been employ’d.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Then gather strength and march unto him straight.
Let him perceive how ill we brook his treason,
And what offense it is to flout his friends.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: I go, my lord, in heart desiring still
You may behold confusion of your foes.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Grant me the combat, gracious sovereign.

speech.speaker: BAS.
speech.line: And me, my lord, grant me the combat too.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: This is my servant, hear him, noble prince.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: And this is mine, sweet Henry, favor him.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Be patient, lords, and give them leave to speak.
Say, gentlemen, what makes you thus exclaim?
And wherefore crave you combat? Or with whom?

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: With him, my lord, for he hath done me wrong.

speech.speaker: BAS.
speech.line: And I with him, for he hath done me wrong.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: What is that wrong whereof you both complain?
First let me know, and then I’ll answer you.

speech.speaker: BAS.
speech.line: Crossing the sea from England into France,
This fellow here, with envious carping tongue,
Upbraided me about the rose I wear,
Saying the sanguine color of the leaves
Did represent my master’s blushing cheeks,
When stubbornly he did repugn the truth
About a certain question in the law
Argu’d betwixt the Duke of York and him;
With other vile and ignominious terms:
In confutation of which rude reproach,
And in defense of my lord’s worthiness,
I crave the benefit of law of arms.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: And that is my petition, noble lord.
For though he seem with forged quaint conceit
To set a gloss upon his bold intent,
Yet know, my lord, I was provok’d by him,
And he first took exceptions at this badge,
Pronouncing that the paleness of this flower
Bewray’d the faintness of my master’s heart.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Will not this malice, Somerset, be left?

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Your private grudge, my Lord of York, will out,
Though ne’er so cunningly you smother it.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Good Lord, what madness rules in brain-sick men,
When for so slight and frivolous a cause
Such factious emulations shall arise!
Good cousins both, of York and Somerset,
Quiet yourselves, I pray, and be at peace.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Let this dissension first be tried by fight,
And then your Highness shall command a peace.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: The quarrel toucheth none but us alone,
Betwixt ourselves let us decide it then.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: There is my pledge, accept it, Somerset.

speech.speaker: VER.
speech.line: Nay, let it rest where it began at first.

speech.speaker: BAS.
speech.line: Confirm it so, mine honorable lord.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Confirm it so? Confounded be your strife,
And perish ye, with your audacious prate!
Presumptuous vassals, are you not asham’d
With this immodest clamorous outrage
To trouble and disturb the King and us?
And you, my lords, methinks you do not well
To bear with their perverse objections;
Much less to take occasion from their mouths
To raise a mutiny betwixt yourselves.
Let me persuade you take a better course.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: It grieves his Highness. Good my lords, be friends.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Come hither, you that would be combatants:
Henceforth I charge you, as you love our favor,
Quite to forget this quarrel, and the cause.
And you, my lords: remember where we are—
In France, amongst a fickle, wavering nation.
If they perceive dissension in our looks,
And that within ourselves we disagree,
How will their grudging stomachs be provok’d
To willful disobedience, and rebel!
Beside, what infamy will there arise,
When foreign princes shall be certified
That for a toy, a thing of no regard,
King Henry’s peers and chief nobility
Destroy’d themselves, and lost the realm of France!
O, think upon the conquest of my father,
My tender years, and let us not forgo
That for a trifle that was bought with blood!
Let me be umpeer in this doubtful strife.
I see no reason, if I wear this rose,
That any one should therefore be suspicious
I more incline to Somerset than York:
Both are my kinsmen, and I love them both.
As well they may upbraid me with my crown,
Because, forsooth, the King of Scots is crown’d.
But your discretions better can persuade
Than I am able to instruct or teach;
And therefore, as we hither came in peace,
So let us still continue peace, and love.
Cousin of York, we institute your Grace
To be our regent in these parts of France;
And, good my Lord of Somerset, unite
Your troops of horsemen with his bands of foot,
And like true subjects, sons of your progenitors,
Go cheerfully together and digest
Your angry choler on your enemies.
Ourself, my Lord Protector, and the rest,
After some respite, will return to Callice;
From thence to England, where I hope ere long
To be presented, by your victories,
With Charles, Alanson, and that traitorous rout.

stagedir.dir: Flourish. Exeunt. Manent York, Warwick, Exeter, Vernon.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: Well didst thou, Richard, to suppress thy voice,
For had the passions of thy heart burst out,
I fear we should have seen decipher’d there
More rancorous spite, more furious raging broils,
Than yet can be imagin’d or suppos’d.
But howsoe’er, no simple man that sees
This jarring discord of nobility,
This shouldering of each other in the court,
This factious bandying of their favorites,
But that it doth presage some ill event.
’Tis much, when sceptres are in children’s hands;
But more, when envy breeds unkind division:
There comes the ruin, there begins confusion.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Go to the gates of Burdeaux, trumpeter,
Summon their general unto the wall.

stagedir.dir: Trumpet sounds. Enter General and others aloft.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: He fables not, I hear the enemy.
Out, some light horsemen, and peruse their wings.
O negligent and heedless discipline!
How are we park’d and bounded in a pale,
A little herd of England’s timorous deer,
Maz’d with a yelping kennel of French curs!
If we be English deer, be then in blood,
Not rascal-like, to fall down with a pinch,
But rather, moody-mad; and, desperate stags,
Turn on the bloody hounds with heads of steel,
And make the cowards stand aloof at bay.
Sell every man his life as dear as mine,
And they shall find dear deer of us, my friends.
God and Saint George, Talbot and England’s right,
Prosper our colors in this dangerous fight!

stagedir.dir: Enter a Messenger that meets York. Enter York with Trumpet and many Soldiers.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: A plague upon that villain Somerset,
That thus delays my promised supply
Of horsemen, that were levied for this siege!
Renowned Talbot doth expect my aid,
And I am louted by a traitor villain
And cannot help the noble chevalier.
God comfort him in this necessity!
If he miscarry, farewell wars in France!

stagedir.dir: Enter another Messenger, Sir William Lucy.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: Thou princely leader of our English strength,
Never so needful on the earth of France,
Spur to the rescue of the noble Talbot,
Who now is girdled with a waist of iron
And hemm’d about with grim destruction.
To Burdeaux, warlike Duke! To Burdeaux, York!
Else farewell Talbot, France, and England’s honor!

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: O God, that Somerset, who in proud heart
Doth stop my cornets, were in Talbot’s place!
So should we save a valiant gentleman
By forfeiting a traitor and a coward.
Mad ire and wrathful fury makes me weep,
That thus we die, while remiss traitors sleep.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: O, send some succor to the distress’d lord!

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: He dies, we lose; I break my warlike word;
We mourn, France smiles; we lose, they daily get;
All long of this vile traitor Somerset.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: Then God take mercy on brave Talbot’s soul,
And on his son young John, who two hours since
I met in travel toward his warlike father!
This seven years did not Talbot see his son,
And now they meet where both their lives are done.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Alas, what joy shall noble Talbot have
To bid his young son welcome to his grave?
Away! Vexation almost stops my breath,
That sund’red friends greet in the hour of death.
Lucy, farewell, no more my fortune can,
But curse the cause I cannot aid the man.
Maine, Blois, Poictiers, and Tours, are won away,
Long all of Somerset and his delay.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: It is too late, I cannot send them now.
This expedition was by York and Talbot
Too rashly plotted. All our general force
Might with a sally of the very town
Be buckled with. The over-daring Talbot
Hath sullied all his gloss of former honor
By this unheedful, desperate, wild adventure.
York set him on to fight and die in shame,
That, Talbot dead, great York might bear the name.

speech.speaker: CAPT.
speech.line: Here is Sir William Lucy, who with me
Set from our o’ermatch’d forces forth for aid.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: How now, Sir William, whither were you sent?

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: Whither, my lord? From bought and sold Lord Talbot,
Who, ring’d about with bold adversity,
Cries out for noble York and Somerset
To beat assailing death from his weak legions;
And whiles the honorable captain there
Drops bloody sweat from his war-wearied limbs,
And, in advantage ling’ring, looks for rescue,
You, his false hopes, the trust of England’s honor,
Keep off aloof with worthless emulation.
Let not your private discord keep away
The levied succors that should lend him aid,
While he, renowned noble gentleman,
Yield up his life unto a world of odds.
Orleance the Bastard, Charles, Burgundy,
Alanson, Reignier, compass him about,
And Talbot perisheth by your default.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: York set him on, York should have sent him aid.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: And York as fast upon your Grace exclaims,
Swearing that you withhold his levied host,
Collected for this expedition.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: York lies; he might have sent, and had the horse.
I owe him little duty, and less love,
And take foul scorn to fawn on him by sending.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: The fraud of England, not the force of France,
Hath now entrapp’d the noble-minded Talbot:
Never to England shall he bear his life,
But dies, betray’d to fortune by your strife.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: Come go, I will dispatch the horsemen straight;
Within six hours they will be at his aid.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: Too late comes rescue, he is ta’en or slain;
For fly he could not, if he would have fled;
And fly would Talbot never, though he might.

speech.speaker: SOM.
speech.line: If he be dead, brave Talbot, then adieu!

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: His fame lives in the world, his shame in you.

stagedir.dir: Enter Talbot and his son, John.

speech.speaker: TAL.
speech.line: Where is my other life? Mine own is gone.
O, where’s young Talbot? Where is valiant John?
Triumphant Death, smear’d with captivity,
Young Talbot’s valor makes me smile at thee.
When he perceiv’d me shrink and on my knee,
His bloody sword he brandish’d over me,
And like a hungry lion did commence
Rough deeds of rage and stern impatience;
But when my angry guardant stood alone,
Tend’ring my ruin and assail’d of none,
Dizzy-ey’d fury and great rage of heart
Suddenly made him from my side to start
Into the clust’ring battle of the French;
And in that sea of blood my boy did drench
His overmounting spirit; and there died
My Icarus, my blossom, in his pride.

stagedir.dir: Enter Soldiers with John Talbot borne.
Enter Charles, Alanson, Burgundy, Bastard, and Pucelle with forces.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: Herald, conduct me to the Dauphin’s tent,
To know who hath obtain’d the glory of the day.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: On what submissive message art thou sent?

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: Submission, Dauphin? ’Tis a mere French word;
We English warriors wot not what it means.
I come to know what prisoners thou hast ta’en,
And to survey the bodies of the dead.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: For prisoners ask’st thou? Hell our prison is.
But tell me whom thou seek’st.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: But where’s the great Alcides of the field,
Valiant Lord Talbot, Earl of Shrewsbury,
Created, for his rare success in arms,
Great Earl of Washford, Waterford, and Valence,
Lord Talbot of Goodrig and Urchinfield,
Lord Strange of Blackmere, Lord Verdon of Alton,
Lord Cromwell of Wingfield, Lord Furnival of Sheffield,
The thrice-victorious Lord of Falconbridge,
Knight of the noble Order of Saint George,
Worthy Saint Michael, and the Golden Fleece,
Great marshal to Henry the Sixth
Of all his wars within the realm of France?

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Here’s a silly stately style indeed!
The Turk, that two and fifty kingdoms hath,
Writes not so tedious a style as this.
Him that thou magnifi’st with all these titles
Stinking and fly-blown lies here at our feet.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: Is Talbot slain, the Frenchmen’s only scourge,
Your kingdom’s terror and black Nemesis?
O, were mine eyeballs into bullets turn’d,
That I in rage might shoot them at your faces!
O, that I could but call these dead to life,
It were enough to fright the realm of France!
Were but his picture left amongst you here,
It would amaze the proudest of you all.
Give me their bodies, that I may bear them hence
And give them burial as beseems their worth.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: I think this upstart is old Talbot’s ghost,
He speaks with such a proud commanding spirit.
For God’s sake let him have ’em; to keep them here,
They would but stink, and putrefy the air.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Go take their bodies hence.

speech.speaker: LUCY.
speech.line: I’ll bear them hence; but from their ashes shall be rear’d
A phoenix that shall make all France afeard.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: So we be rid of them, do with ’em what thou wilt.
And now to Paris in this conquering vein,
All will be ours, now bloody Talbot’s slain.

scene.scenelocation: London. A room in the palace.

scenepersonae.scenepersona: Ambassador from the Earl of Armagnac

stagedir.dir: Sennet. Enter King, Gloucester, and Exeter.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: What, is my Lord of Winchester install’d,
And call’d unto a cardinal’s degree?
Then I perceive that will be verified
Henry the Fifth did sometime prophesy:
“If once he come to be a cardinal,
He’ll make his cap co-equal with the crown.”

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: My lords ambassadors, your several suits
Have been consider’d and debated on.
Your purpose is both good and reasonable;
And therefore are we certainly resolv’d
To draw conditions of a friendly peace,
Which by my Lord of Winchester we mean
Shall be transported presently to France.

speech.speaker: WIN.
speech.line: Stay, my lord legate, you shall first receive
The sum of money which I promised
Should be delivered to his Holiness
For clothing me in these grave ornaments.

speech.speaker: PAP.
speech.line: I will attend upon your lordship’s leisure.

stagedir.dir: Enter Charles, Burgundy, Alanson, Bastard, Reignier, and Joan de Pucelle, with forces.

speech.speaker: SCOUT.
speech.line: Success unto our valiant general,
And happiness to his accomplices!

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: What tidings send our scouts? I prithee speak.

speech.speaker: SCOUT.
speech.line: The English army, that divided was
Into two parties, is now conjoin’d in one,
And means to give you battle presently.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Somewhat too sudden, sirs, the warning is,
But we will presently provide for them.

speech.speaker: BUR.
speech.line: I trust the ghost of Talbot is not there.
Now he is gone, my lord, you need not fear.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Of all base passions, fear is most accurs’d.
Command the conquest, Charles, it shall be thine,
Let Henry fret, and all the world repine.

speech.speaker: CHAR.
speech.line: Then on, my lords, and France be fortunate!

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Excursions. Enter Joan de Pucelle.

scene.line: This speedy and quick appearance argues proof
Of your accustom’d diligence to me.
Now, ye familiar spirits, that are cull’d
Out of the powerful regions under earth,
Help me this once, that France may get the field.
O, hold me not with silence over-long!
Where I was wont to feed you with my blood,
I’ll lop a member off and give it you
In earnest of a further benefit,
So you do condescend to help me now.
No hope to have redress? My body shall
Pay recompense, if you will grant my suit.
Cannot my body nor blood-sacrifice
Entreat you to your wonted furtherance?
Then take my soul—my body, soul, and all,
Before that England give the French the foil.
See, they forsake me! Now the time is come
That France must vail her lofty-plumed crest
And let her head fall into England’s lap.
My ancient incantations are too weak,
And hell too strong for me to buckle with:
Now, France, thy glory droopeth to the dust.

stagedir.dir: French fly. Pucelle is brought in captive.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Damsel of France, I think I have you fast:
Unchain your spirits now with spelling charms,
And try if they can gain your liberty.
A goodly prize, fit for the devil’s grace!
See how the ugly witch doth bend her brows,
As if, with Circe, she would change my shape!

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Chang’d to a worser shape thou canst not be.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: O, Charles the Dauphin is a proper man,
No shape but his can please your dainty eye.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: A plaguing mischief light on Charles and thee!
And may ye both be suddenly surpris’d
By bloody hands, in sleeping on your beds!

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Fell banning hag, enchantress, hold thy tongue!

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: I prithee give me leave to curse a while.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Curse, miscreant, when thou com’st to the stake.

stagedir.dir: Alarum. Enter Suffolk with Margaret in his hand.

scene.line: I have no power to let her pass,
My hand would free her, but my heart says no.
As plays the sun upon the glassy streams,
Twinkling another counterfeited beam,
So seems this gorgeous beauty to mine eyes.
Fain would I woo her, yet I dare not speak:
I’ll call for pen and ink, and write my mind.
Fie, De la Pole, disable not thyself.
Hast not a tongue? Is she not here?
Wilt thou be daunted at a woman’s sight?
Ay; beauty’s princely majesty is such,
’Confounds the tongue and makes the senses rough.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Say, Earl of Suffolk—if thy name be so—
What ransom must I pay before I pass?
For I perceive I am thy prisoner.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: How canst thou tell she will deny thy suit,
Before thou make a trial of her love?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Why speak’st thou not? What ransom must I pay?

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: She’s beautiful; and therefore to be wooed:
She is a woman; therefore to be won.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Wilt thou accept of ransom, yea or no?

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Fond man, remember that thou hast a wife,
Then how can Margaret be thy paramour?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I were best to leave him, for he will not hear.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: There all is marr’d; there lies a cooling card.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: He talks at randon; sure the man is mad.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: And yet a dispensation may be had.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: And yet I would that you would answer me.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: I’ll win this Lady Margaret. For whom?
Why, for my king. Tush, that’s a wooden thing!

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: He talks of wood; it is some carpenter.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Yet so my fancy may be satisfied,
And peace established between these realms.
But there remains a scruple in that too;
For though her father be the King of Naples,
Duke of Anjou and Maine, yet is he poor,
And our nobility will scorn the match.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Hear ye, captain? Are you not at leisure?

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: It shall be so, disdain they ne’er so much.
Henry is youthful and will quickly yield.—
Madam, I have a secret to reveal.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: What though I be enthrall’d, he seems a knight,
And will not any way dishonor me.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Lady, vouchsafe to listen what I say.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Perhaps I shall be rescu’d by the French,
And then I need not crave his courtesy.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Sweet madam, give me hearing in a cause.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Tush, women have been captivate ere now.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Lady, wherefore talk you so?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I cry you mercy, ’tis but quid for quo.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Say, gentle Princess, would you not suppose
Your bondage happy, to be made a queen?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: To be a queen in bondage is more vile
Than is a slave in base servility;
For princes should be free.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: And so shall you,
If happy England’s royal king be free.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Why, what concerns his freedom unto me?

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: I’ll undertake to make thee Henry’s queen,
To put a golden sceptre in thy hand,
And set a precious crown upon thy head,
If thou wilt condescend to be my—

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: What?

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: His love.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: I am unworthy to be Henry’s wife.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: No, gentle madam, I unworthy am
To woo so fair a dame to be his wife
And have no portion in the choice myself.
How say you, madam, are ye so content?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: And if my father please, I am content.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Then call our captains and our colors forth,
And, madam, at your father’s castle walls
We’ll crave a parley, to confer with him.

stagedir.dir: Sound a parley. Enter Reignier on the walls.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: And here I will expect thy coming.
And yet methinks I could be well content
To be mine own attorney in this case.—
I’ll over then to England with this news,
And make this marriage to be solemniz’d.
So farewell, Reignier! Set this diamond safe
In golden palaces, as it becomes.

speech.speaker: REIG.
speech.line: I do embrace thee, as I would embrace
The Christian prince, King Henry, were he here.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Farewell, my lord! Good wishes, praise, and prayers
Shall Suffolk ever have of Margaret.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Farewell, sweet madam! But hark you, Margaret,
No princely commendations to my king?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Such commendations as becomes a maid,
A virgin, and his servant, say to him.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Words sweetly plac’d and modestly directed.
But, madam, I must trouble you again,
No loving token to his Majesty?

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: Yes, my good lord, a pure unspotted heart,
Never yet taint with love, I send the King.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: And this withal.

speech.speaker: MAR.
speech.line: That for thyself; I will not so presume
To send such peevish tokens to a king.

scene.scenelocation: Anjou. Camp of the Duke of York.

stagedir.dir: Enter York, Warwick, Shepherd, Pucelle guarded.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Take her away, for she hath liv’d too long,
To fill the world with vicious qualities.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: First let me tell you whom you have condemn’d:
Not me begotten of a shepherd swain,
But issued from the progeny of kings;
Virtuous and holy, chosen from above,
By inspiration of celestial grace,
To work exceeding miracles on earth.
I never had to do with wicked spirits.
But you, that are polluted with your lusts,
Stain’d with the guiltless blood of innocents,
Corrupt and tainted with a thousand vices,
Because you want the grace that others have,
You judge it straight a thing impossible
To compass wonders but by help of devils.
No, misconceived! Joan of Aire hath been
A virgin from her tender infancy,
Chaste, and immaculate in very thought,
Whose maiden blood, thus rigorously effus’d,
Will cry for vengeance at the gates of heaven.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Ay, ay; away with her to execution!

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: And hark ye, sirs: because she is a maid,
Spare for no faggots, let there be enow.
Place barrels of pitch upon the fatal stake,
That so her torture may be shortened.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Will nothing turn your unrelenting hearts?
Then, Joan, discover thine infirmity,
That warranteth by law to be thy privilege.
I am with child, ye bloody homicides!
Murder not then the fruit within my womb,
Although ye hale me to a violent death.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Now heaven forfend, the holy maid with child?

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: The greatest miracle that e’er ye wrought!
Is all your strict preciseness come to this?

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: She and the Dauphin have been juggling.
I did imagine what would be her refuge.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Well, go to, we’ll have no bastards live,
Especially since Charles must father it.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: You are deceiv’d, my child is none of his,
It was Alanson that enjoy’d my love.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Alanson, that notorious Machevile?
It dies, and if it had a thousand lives.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: O, give me leave, I have deluded you,
’Twas neither Charles nor yet the duke I nam’d,
But Reignier, King of Naples, that prevail’d.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: A married man! That’s most intolerable.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Why, here’s a girl! I think she knows not well
(There were so many) whom she may accuse.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: It’s sign she hath been liberal and free.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: And yet forsooth she is a virgin pure.
Strumpet, thy words condemn thy brat and thee.
Use no entreaty, for it is in vain.

speech.speaker: PUC.
speech.line: Then lead me hence; with whom I leave my curse:
May never glorious sun reflex his beams
Upon the country where you make abode;
But darkness and the gloomy shade of death
Environ you, till mischief and despair
Drive you to break your necks or hang yourselves!

speech.speaker: CAR.
speech.line: Lord Regent, I do greet your Excellence
With letters of commission from the King.
For know, my lords, the states of Christendom,
Mov’d with remorse of these outrageous broils,
Have earnestly implor’d a general peace
Betwixt our nation and the aspiring French;
And here at hand the Dauphin and his train
Approacheth, to confer about some matter.

speech.speaker: YORK.
speech.line: Is all our travail turn’d to this effect?
After the slaughter of so many peers,
So many captains, gentlemen, and soldiers,
That in this quarrel have been overthrown
And sold their bodies for their country’s benefit,
Shall we at last conclude effeminate peace?
Have we not lost most part of all the towns,
By treason, falsehood, and by treachery,
Our great progenitors had conquered?
O Warwick, Warwick, I foresee with grief
The utter loss of all the realm of France.

speech.speaker: WAR.
speech.line: Be patient, York. If we conclude a peace,
It shall be with such strict and severe covenants,
As little shall the Frenchmen gain thereby.

stagedir.dir: Enter Charles, Alanson, Bastard, Reignier, and others.

scene.line: My lord, you do not well in obstinacy
To cavil in the course of this contract.
If once it be neglected, ten to one
We shall not find like opportunity.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Your wondrous rare description, noble Earl,
Of beauteous Margaret hath astonish’d me.
Her virtues, graced with external gifts,
Do breed love’s settled passions in my heart,
And like as rigor of tempestuous gusts
Provokes the mightiest hulk against the tide,
So am I driven by breath of her renown,
Either to suffer shipwrack, or arrive
Where I may have fruition of her love.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Tush, my good lord, this superficial tale
Is but a preface of her worthy praise.
The chief perfections of that lovely dame
(Had I sufficient skill to utter them)
Would make a volume of enticing lines,
Able to ravish any dull conceit;
And, which is more, she is not so divine,
So full replete with choice of all delights,
But with as humble lowliness of mind
She is content to be at your command—
Command, I mean, of virtuous chaste intents,
To love and honor Henry as her lord.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: And otherwise will Henry ne’er presume.
Therefore, my Lord Protector, give consent
That Marg’ret may be England’s royal queen.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: So should I give consent to flatter sin.
You know, my lord, your Highness is betroth’d
Unto another lady of esteem.
How shall we then dispense with that contract,
And not deface your honor with reproach?

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: As doth a ruler with unlawful oaths,
Or one that at a triumph, having vow’d
To try his strength, forsaketh yet the lists
By reason of his adversary’s odds.
A poor earl’s daughter is unequal odds,
And therefore may be broke without offense.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: Why, what, I pray, is Margaret more than that?
Her father is no better than an earl,
Although in glorious titles he excel.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Yes, my lord, her father is a king,
The King of Naples and Jerusalem,
And of such great authority in France
As his alliance will confirm our peace,
And keep the Frenchmen in allegiance.

speech.speaker: GLOU.
speech.line: And so the Earl of Armagnac may do,
Because he is near kinsman unto Charles.

speech.speaker: EXE.
speech.line: Beside, his wealth doth warrant a liberal dower,
Where Reignier sooner will receive than give.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: A dow’r, my lords? Disgrace not so your king,
That he should be so abject, base, and poor,
To choose for wealth and not for perfect love.
Henry is able to enrich his queen,
And not to seek a queen to make him rich:
So worthless peasants bargain for their wives,
As market men for oxen, sheep, or horse.
Marriage is a matter of more worth
Than to be dealt in by attorneyship.
Not whom we will, but whom his Grace affects,
Must be companion of his nuptial bed.
And therefore, lords, since he affects her most,
Most of all these reasons bindeth us
In our opinions she should be preferr’d.
For what is wedlock forced, but a hell,
An age of discord and continual strife?
Whereas the contrary bringeth bliss,
And is a pattern of celestial peace.
Whom should we match with Henry, being a king,
But Margaret, that is daughter to a king?
Her peerless feature, joined with her birth,
Approves her fit for none but for a king.
Her valiant courage and undaunted spirit
(More than in women commonly is seen)
Will answer our hope in issue of a king;
For Henry, son unto a conqueror,
Is likely to beget more conquerors,
If with a lady of so high resolve
(As is fair Margaret) he be link’d in love.
Then yield, my lords, and here conclude with me
That Margaret shall be Queen, and none but she.

speech.speaker: KING.
speech.line: Whether it be through force of your report,
My noble Lord of Suffolk, or for that
My tender youth was never yet attaint
With any passion of inflaming love,
I cannot tell; but this I am assur’d,
I feel such sharp dissension in my breast,
Such fierce alarums both of hope and fear,
As I am sick with working of my thoughts.
Take therefore shipping, post, my lord, to France,
Agree to any covenants, and procure
That Lady Margaret do vouchsafe to come
To cross the seas to England and be crown’d
King Henry’s faithful and anointed queen.
For your expenses and sufficient charge,
Among the people gather up a tenth.
Be gone, I say, for till you do return,
I rest perplexed with a thousand cares.
And you, good uncle, banish all offense.
If you do censure me by what you were,
Not what you are, I know it will excuse
This sudden execution of my will.
And so conduct me where, from company,
I may revolve and ruminate my grief.

speech.speaker: SUF.
speech.line: Thus Suffolk hath prevail’d, and thus he goes,
As did the youthful Paris once to Greece,
With hope to find the like event in love,
But prosper better than the Troyan did.
Margaret shall now be Queen, and rule the King;
But I will rule both her, the King, and realm.
